awd_titl_txt: AGS-PRF: Establishing Causality in the Angular Momentum Budget of the Atmosphere: Insights from the Quasi-Biennial Oscillation
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

The Quasi-Biennial Oscillation (QBO) describes the alternating direction of the longitudinally averaged equatorial wind in the middle-to-lower stratosphere at roughly every 27 months. Over time, this alternating pattern descends toward the tropopause before diminishing at the altitude range of 13-19 km. In this range, the QBO can influence the tropospheric jet stream and tropical convection, thereby affecting the global weather and climate. The diminished QBO wind can be attributed to the atmospheric torque associated with the dissipation of atmospheric waves propagating upward into the tropopause region. To date, the impact of the atmospheric torque on the QBO and, eventually, on the tropospheric circulation is not well understood. Current climate models cannot properly simulate the observed descent of the QBO eastward wind across the tropopause, and this failure may be due to the improper torque representation in models.

This work aims to advance our understanding of atmospheric torque and the global influence of the QBO. Mentored by a well-established sponsor, the investigator will use observations and numerical models of varying complexity to address this goal. The research tasks will focus on testing theories on the torque-QBO relationship in observations and models, assessing the influence of the QBO on the mid-latitude jet, and quantifying the influence of torques on tropical convection. These efforts could help advance future modeling capabilities by improving climate projections and subseasonal-to-seasonal forecasts of regional precipitation and mid-latitude jet dynamics. The investigator will also make public-engagement presentations to provide insight into climate change related to the research work.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Sunscreen protects us from ultraviolet (UV) light emitted by the Sun, which can otherwise burn skin and damage DNA. Fortunately for life as we know it, most of the UV light that hits Earth never reaches the ground, instead being absorbed by the atmosphere. Some of this UV is absorbed by oxygen molecules (O2), breaking them apart (called photolysis) and leading to the formation of ozone (O3). Most of the UV is then absorbed by ozone itself, in a cycle of photolysis then reformation. This absorption by ozone heats the stratosphere, causing temperature to increase with height and affecting the large-scale winds, which can in turn move ozone around. This project has investigated the interplay of chemistry, winds, sunlight, and temperature in the tropical stratosphere, advancing understanding of what sets the basic structure of the stratosphere and its sensitivity to perturbations from changes in ozone and global warming.

The ozone layer has been affected by human actions, with the infamous ozone hole being formed by ozone-depleting substances such as chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), which are now banned under the Montreal Protocol. Global warming also affects the ozone layer, generally leading to increases in ozone except in the tropical lower stratosphere, where ozone is projected to decrease. These reductions in the tropical lower stratosphere have generally been explained to occur because global warming leads to a strengthening of upward winds there, thereby more vigorously freshening the tropical lower stratosphere with ozone-poor air from below. This project has demonstrated an additional reason for these ozone reductions: global warming causes the entire troposphere to expand upwards, eroding the stratosphere and reducing ozone from below. These reductions in ozone are then smeared upwards into the lower stratosphere by the upward winds. These two mechanisms---strengthening upward winds and tropospheric expansion---contribute comparably to ozone reductions under global warming. Understanding the distinct role played by these two mechanisms has improved our understanding of the ozone response to global warming and emphasized the importance of tropospheric processes in stratospheric ozone change.

The reductions of ozone in the tropical lower stratosphere and increases in ozone in the tropical upper stratosphere under global warming have been noted to resemble an upward shift of the ozone profile along with the rising tropopause (the interface between the troposphere and stratosphere). For this reason, numerous studies have attempted to remove the effects of global warming on ozone by analyzing ozone trends relative to the tropopause. We have found that a rising tropopause does lead to an upward shift in ozone in the tropical lower stratosphere, but not in the upper stratosphere. The apparent upward shift in ozone in the upper stratosphere actually results from stratospheric cooling, which is largely independent of the tropopause and therefore only resembles tropospheric expansion by coincidence. We have developed a theory of the ozone response to stratospheric cooling that quantifies this apparent upward shift. These results suggest that tropopause-following coordinates lack rigorous justification and do not generally remove the effects of global warming.

Our theory for the ozone response to stratospheric cooling emerges from a general framework for understanding the ozone response to photochemical perturbations. This theory helps us understand "ozone self-healing", which occurs when ozone-depleting processes lead to seemingly-paradoxical increases in ozone. Self-healing occurs because depleted ozone aloft allows UV light to penetrate into the atmosphere, where it increases the production of ozone. Self-healing occurs where the ozone layer is photochemically stabilizing, but we have also uncovered substantial areas of photochemical destabilization. These photochemical regimes have been contextualized within a theoretical framework emphasizing how O2 and O3 interact with UV light at different wavelengths. 

This new framework for understanding how different wavelengths of light affect the ozone layer has revealed connections between the photochemical sensitivities and basic shape of the ozone layer. We have revisited explanations for the basic shape of the ozone layer and found various mutually-inconsistent ways of explaining this fundamental fact of our atmosphere in textbooks and papers. We use our new framework to evaluate these competing explanations and clarify how different explanations can apply under different assumptions about ozone transport and destruction.

Towards the Broader Impacts of this postdoctoral fellowship, the PI has contributed to public scientific literacy through the organization he co-founded called Climate Up Close. Climate Up Close is a group of climate scientists who tour the country presenting a non-prescriptive primer on the scientific consensus on climate change, distilled from climate assessments such as the IPCC. We seek to be honest brokers of the science, helping our fellow Americans filter out distorted claims in order to have a clear view of climate change. During this fellowship, Climate Up Close toured the Florida Panhandle, Central New Jersey, and the Chicago area.
